ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
MR HO JUAN THAI


    1. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will give a categorical assurance that Mr Ho Juan Thai will not be detained under the Internal Security Act if and when he returns to Singapore.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr J B Jeyaretnam's request is ridiculous. Mr Ho is not above the law. The Government cannot give an assurance to Mr Ho that amounts to perpetual immunity over the laws of the land which include the Internal Security Act.

    If Mr Ho is genuinely interested to return to Singapore, he should take up the Government's offer of a one-way Document of Identity to return. As mentioned to the House previously, Mr Ho will be questioned by the relevant authorities for possible offences under the Immigration Act and the Enlistment Act as well as over his racially inflammatory speeches at election rallies during the December 1976 General Election.

    If Mr Ho is guilty of any wrong-doing that warrants his arrest or detention under any law, Mr Ho must be dealt with accordingly.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): May I tell the Minister of State that my question is directed particularly at detention under the Internal Security Act. Is the Minister aware that for altering the passport he could be prosecuted under the Penal Code or the Passports Act, similarly, for evading National Service under the National Enlistment Act? What is the offence for which the ISD wish to question him under the Internal Security Act?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I think the answer makes it very clear. The ISD would like to question him over his inflammatory remarks made in 1976 during the general election.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister tell us what were these inflammatory speeches? Were they not what the present Government is advocating, ie, he was calling for greater use of Mandarin and, particularly, for students at Nanyang University to take their examinations in Mandarin, and not in English?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, I think Mr Jeyaretnam is being very simplistic. Column: 858



    Sir, the Government Parliamentary Committee has submitted the review of the Vehicle Quota System and we have made some specific recommendations with the terms of reference set by the Minister. I will not go into the details of this report which have been variously carried in the press.

    One of the most impressive statements that I heard during all those hours of discussions and dialogues came from a freight forwarder. After all the feedback and complaints, as usual, during a 3-hour session, he stood up and confessed that in all his more than 30 years of the freighting business in Singapore, only today, in spite of so many vehicles on the road, can he really be confident to plan and execute a freight operation from one end of Singapore to the port, to time it such that there is a minimum of delay and time loss, and in the shortest possible time, in order for his goods to go up the container vessel berthed at the port just in time. He does this every day in his business. He attributed this to the VQS and the Government's forward looking systematic policies on land transport in Singapore. It is the power of technology and system and political will. This was the greatest compliment I heard for the Minister and his Ministry. Unfortunately, the Minister was not there, and it is not in the report.

    The Report made several recommendations which I will just highlight in order to give other Members the chance to have a go at it. We recommended to retain the system, although we went into it with an open mind. We found large support for the retention of the system with the lowest successful bid approach as against the pay-as-you-bid approach. We recommended that the Government should consider raising the cap of 3% in view of the ERP system which can address usage costs more efficiently.

    We also recommended the merging of Categories 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 into two classes, the line being drawn at the 1,600 cc. Ideally, we believe there should be one category of cars. We do not recommend loading the already complicated COE system with all kinds of social equity reasons and factors, so that the

Column: 859

value, benefit and costs are transparent and clear to all. Of course, we cannot completely dismantle the present system, but the Minister should be clear of our direction.

    By giving a bigger category size, ie, a larger number of COE quota with the merged category, we should find more competition, choice and a more stable outcome. In fact, too small a category size leads to a high possibility of an anomalous outcome. Merging the categories also gives wider choice of cars, and a more competitive environment for business benefiting the larger number of consumers.

    We also recommended to even out the surge in COE in the year 2000 by distributing it over two years, namely, 2000 and 2001. For everyone who owns or successfully bids for a COE, the Government must also be able to justify to the larger population who use public transport and pay taxes, that the road infrastructures are put to good use and social benefits and costs must also be weighed against private benefits and costs. The Government must be fair overall and not just please or bow to one section of car dealers or population who may have their own preferences or legitimate interests.

    We are for a more dynamic mechanism with a revised formula that collapses the time lag and allocates the distribution to reflect changing preferences of the car buying public, instead of being locked into a distribution function of COEs that reflect preferences 10 years ago.

    We also made a recommendation for a trial out of an open-bid system in the open category. I will go into this a while. After all these recommendations, we ended with a prayer. We hope the dealers will provide a more transparent and arm's length, above-the-table engagement with customers, especially those who bid on their own. We do not believe all the unfavourable comments we have received on the dealers are justified, and we do not agree to the call to ban them from bidding. We believe they perform a service in the economy. The solution is to

Column: 860

make the system more transparent and even out the information discrepancies arising from knowledge of market and experience in bidding or collusive power. Ten years ago, the technology and processes did not allow such a wide area open bid to be possible but today with information technology and computing power, electronic bidding goes on all over the world, every minute of the day.

    There are many ways in which an auction can be conducted. It puzzles me how before the model is even specified or developed, a writer to the Straits Times yesterday can talk of the flaws of an open-bid system. Caricatures of it appeared in the press, like frenzied bidding for some rare art piece or the seventh moon or-kim. However, it will not be the first time an electronic real time open bid auction is done in Singapore. The pig auction in Singapore is done electronically on a real time open bid basis daily. It has been done so for more than 10 years. Do we find the prices of pork unduly higher because of some cornering of pork for market share or some frenzied consumption of pork over the last 10 years? The person responsible for developing this open bid real time electronic auction system for pigs more than 10 years ago is sitting very comfortably in the front bench as Minister and Government Whip. Of course, the technology was different but the fundamental concept is the same.

    Naturally, rules apply for such bid processes. Hence, I am confident the study will come out with a model, which can overcome the many fears expressed. I wish to thank all for the feedback. No one can give you the outcome of a bid process, whether it is going to be high or low. If he can, it has been fixed. The COE allocation or bidding mechanism can only take care of the supply side. We should make it more stable and predictable, more transparent. The demand side depends on the buyers. It depends on rationality, information power, income, economic outlook, expectations and the value perceived by buyers.

    The open-bid system gives a more transparent model with information to

Column: 861

the buyers. The mandate to bid can also be given to a dealer but the mandate is transparent between the buyer and the dealer. This way the buyer knows exactly what the dealer is bidding on his behalf or whether it is within the mandate. Alternatively, the buyer bids on his own. In a close bid system, the information is not revealed.

    There are many kinds of auction systems that are practised by businesses all over the world. For example, there is the one-sided auction, the two-sided auction, the Dutch auction and the English auction. However, unfortunately, what we are more familiar here is only the seventh moon auction.

    The open bid model we are advocating that fits our system is the one-sided open competitive bid auction, with the lowest successful bid. It can be coupled with a Dutch auction where you bid down, or an English auction method where you bid up. I suggest we leave the details and the process to the study committee, which will come out with the proper model that can address the real nitty-gritty issues.

    The field of experimental economics is full of such case studies. There is a wealth of literature to draw on.

    All over the world today, consumers want to have the information and the power to choose and decide. Companies with hundreds of billions of dollars of sales are studying ways and means towards a more efficient consumer response using IT, with more rational processes. They are all re-evaluating and re-constructing their supply chain using IT for efficient processes. All over the world, electronic bids are done on the Internet, for example, E-bay dot.com. Business process will have to change to a more efficient way of doing things for the open world. The same goes for the bidding system.

    Singaporeans deserve and should be given the information and the responsibility for their decision and action. The

Column: 862

consumers will have an important say in this and will determine the outcome of the bid which will reflect the social market value.

12.45 pm

    Dr Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Sir, I sat on the VQS Review Committee as a member of the GPC for Communications. Unavoidable, of course, I brought in my experiences as a consumer advocate, being the President of the Consumers' Association of Singapore.

    The VQS is not a consumer issue directly. It is a mechanism to allocate scarce resources. It is a mechanism whereby the Government decides that the growth of vehicles has got to be controlled, and this control mechanism means that the quota is fixed as to who will get cars from this quota. It is what the VQS is all about. In the process of buying a car which is, of course, a consumer issue, the consumer wants to be able to buy with a free choice. In other words, in an ideal system he should be able to get a COE and then go round to shop for his car. And if he leaves the COE with the dealer that does not satisfy his needs after maybe one, two bids, and one month or two months, he can take back the COE and go to another organisation that deals with a different car.

    The problem that the consumer faces is that at this moment, he feels that the system is stacked too much against him, and too much for the dealer. For example, COE, even though it can be bidded in the name of an individual, IC number is given, but the c/o address is always the dealer's address. So the COE goes to the dealer and stays with him. And that means that the dealer has got quite a few COEs in his command. He can command and manipulate prices, and he can hold on to the COE, and tell the consumer, "Look, you go to another dealer, you are not going to get another car, because I have the COE."

Column: 863



    Another situation is where the consumer says, "I will get the COE myself." And he brings this COE to the dealer, and the dealer says, "Hey, you got your own COE, I am not going to sell you a car." Or he says, "Yes, I will sell you the car, but I am not giving you my special offer prices." And this would mean that ultimately the consumer says, "I have no choice." You say I have a choice, but it is a Hobson's choice, it is not a real choice. So it would be good. And I think, having sat on the VQS Committee, argued all these points, I have come to the conclusion that actually, as many consumers do realise, the VQS is a good system and it should be kept. But I think we need to address some of these issues so that ultimately the consumer, for example, knows that he really has a choice. I personally feel, of course, that if you ban dealers from bidding, it is not an answer. Because then we will create actually a new class of professionals called car brokers, car dealers, COE brokers, who will then do what the dealers are doing. Because ultimately some consumers do not have the time, they do want to pay somebody to do it for them.

    I would like to urge the Government when it considers the review of the open bidding system that we build in some measures to make sure that frenzied bidding, cornering of the market and this whole idea that consumers cannot bid because they have no information. all these will be taken care of, so that ultimately, even if there is a bid, the consumers know that it is a fair and level playing field.

    As for suggestions like scaling and pay-as-you-bid system, I would ask the Government to even consider if these things can be worked into the open bidding system.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Sir, there has understandably been much concern and anticipation over the proposed changes to the COE and the Vehicle Quota System. In general, I am supportive of the recommendations made by the GPC Committee on revising the Vehicle Quota System. However, I have

Column: 864

my reservations regarding the proposed open bidding system.

    The present Vehicle Quota System is not perfect. We all know that. However, there are merits to the system, and it has served our purposes very well all these years. The present system of limiting vehicle growth through a quota system should stay. However, refinement or fine-tuning may be necessary. Changes towards more transparency, as recommended by the Committee, whilst beneficial may impact greatly upon existing users and consumers. Hence, I believe the Committee's recommendation of progressive change by trying out the open bidding system with only one category of vehicles at the moment is useful, as it allows consumers and participants in the car market to adjust progressively towards a new system, if it works. This also allows for refinement to the system should open bidding for the open category be subject to abuse and manipulation later on.

    Sir, besides the principles of transparency and gradual change, I am pleased to note that the Committee is also recommending collapsing the two categories down to two broad ones. This is sensible in my mind, as congestion costs for vehicles are not directly correlated with the size of engine capacities for cars. There had been occasions in the past where due to affordability of the smaller capacity vehicle owners, COEs for these smaller categories were higher than those for larger categories. Consumers who have no choice but to purchase less powerful cars unfortunately end up paying more for their COEs, compared to consumers who are able to afford the larger cars.

    I believe the proposal to streamline the categories into two will in part address this anomaly and flatten the spread across the categories, not to mention the freak result of a $50 COE. However, I would like to raise a matter of serious concern - the underlying assumptions of open bidding. Firstly, consumers are rational. We assume that they can make informed decisions that best reflect their self-interest. Secondly, the transparency of

Column: 865

the system in itself would cancel out possible abuses since the free market competition will set the price. Sir, the failure of any or both of these conditions may disadvantage the majority of Singaporean car owners. It is inevitable that there would be asymmetry in information accessed by both the laymen and the specialists in the motor trade. If buyers are allowed to bid and withdraw at will, which may happen in an open bidding system, there could be manipulation of prices by concerted parties who may have an interest in maintaining vehicle price at a particular level.

    Further, Sir, the kiasu mentality of Singaporeans could result in extensive tendering, leading to misallocation of resources. Since, in order to ensure that one gets the COE, it is more likely that competitive bidding may lead to higher prices, which may not necessarily reflect an efficient market pricing for this reason, as well as the potential manipulation of prices by interested parties. This is a matter of serious concern to many Singaporeans who have voiced objection to the open bidding system, considering the difficult economic period that we are all going through.

    Therefore, Sir, I would strongly recommend that along with greater transparency and open bidding, we also try out the pay-as-you-bid system. This would ensure responsible bidding and it would not result in artificially raising the average price through the possible anomalies highlighted above, benefiting all users and consumers in the long run. With a combination of open bidding and pay-as-you-bid system, it is unlikely that the "winner's curse" situation, as argued by the Committee, would result, as consumers would be making bids responsibly based on up-to-date information, and can best reflect their own interest and demand.

    Sir, neither system is without its merits and flaws. I would like to strongly recommend to the Minister that we use the proposed refinements of the categories to test the pay-as-you-bid system

Column: 866

which has a lot of support from the public. For a start, we can continue with the status quo arrangement for the 1,600 cc and below category. We can also take up the Committee's recommendations for open bidding to be experimented with the Open Category. My proposal is that we use the same period in assessing the open bidding system for the Open Category to test the pay-as-you-bid system for the 1,600 cc and above category. This will ensure that we can have a gradual approach to change while evaluating all three systems together, in order to best decide once and for all which is the best system for us. Let us try out the three systems simultaneously among the three categories of vehicles and review them, perhaps, in a year's time, to decide which is an ideal system for us.

    I hope the Minister will take up these suggestions.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Sir, I was one of the members in this Committee. I rise to lend support to my Chairman. And I would like the House to know that we did deliberate very seriously on this matter. We invited so many groups of people to come, representing people of many varied interests, including the individual car owners. So I would say that we did a very thorough study on this matter. And I thought that at this juncture, after having heard Mr Chew Heng Ching mentioning the pay-as-you-bid system, maybe I would like to state our Committee's reasons why we did not accept the pay-as-you-bid proposal.

    The Committee actually received several suggestions to replace the current single strike price system, with the pay-as-you-bid system, or its variations such as asking the top 10% or 20% successful bidders to pay their bid amounts. We have given these suggestions due consideration in the course of our review. The Committee is of the view that the pay-as-you-bid system is not superior to the current system. It has its own shortcomings. But some of the feedback received by the Committee had expressed the following concerns about the pay-as-you-bid system. There could be an additional source of discontent among the

Column: 867

successful bidders as no one likes the idea of having to pay more for the same item. Only the ones paying the lowest premiums would be happy. Some laymen might have difficulties in deciding on the right price to bid, for fear that they might be penalised for bidding too high. This could lead to greater reliance on motor vehicle dealers.

    The pay-as-you-bid system will cause confusion in the motor vehicle trade and vehicle financing industry. Some economists and academics have expressed the view that the pay-as-you-bid system could establish a stronger incentive for collusion among motor vehicle dealers to ensure that they bid close to the lowest successful price. The Committee also felt that it was not fair to always penalise the top 10% or 20% bidders, especially if their bids are close to the lowest strike price. Based on the statistics of past tender exercises, the Committee noted the trend that bids were converging towards the low as you bid. Generally, the successful bids clustered around the 20% to 30% above the lowest strike price.

    Taking the above into consideration, the Committee decided that the current method based on the price of the lowest successful bid should be retained. I may not have given him the best answer he wants, but maybe later on in the course of the debate we could discuss further. But I do hope the Minister will really take into consideration all the proposals that we have made, and perhaps give them a try, especially the open bidding system for the open category.
1.00 pm

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Pasir Ris): Sir, I read with great interest the Report of the Vehicle Quota System Review Committee and can appreciate the difficulties faced by the Committee as it tried to grapple with and balance the various conflicting issues about social equity, car categories, quota size and the myriad of factors that make the subject of vehicle ownership in Singapore such a talked-about and emotive one.

Column: 868



    The Vehicle Quota System was introduced 10 years ago. For all its flaws and inadequacies, I believe the system is working reasonably well. Prices of COE have stabilised at a level that is appropriate in the light of the present state of our economy. This shows that buyers are rational and notwithstanding the initial fears, prices of COEs had not shot through the roof except for a brief period in the midst of a booming economy, rife speculation and material excesses. Over the last 12 months, prices have been moving within a band of between $20,000 and $40,000. There was resistance when prices hit the high 30s and when prices came down to the low 20s, buyers entered the market.

    The Vehicle Quota System is maturing. We should give it some more time and let it stabilise further. At this stage, we should not make drastic changes merely for the change alone. As far as possible, we should not introduce any more uncertainties into the system. Uncertainties leading to wide fluctuations in prices are detrimental to dealers, owners, aspiring car buyers and the financial institutions which finance them. It can also be a source of discontent. How many of us have experienced situations where after we have bought an item, the price of that item dropped the very next month because of some changes in Government policy. A recent example is the prevailing quota premium which fell significantly as a result of the change in computation from a 12-month to a 3-month moving average. The converse is when we have not bought the item yet and the price shoots up because of a change in policy.

    Sir, I would now like to touch on three of the Committee's observations which I have reservations about. They are (1) the distribution of COEs among the different categories, (2) merger of Categories 1 and 2, and (3) the proposed open tender system.

    Regarding the first issue, in principle, I agree that vehicle quota should be distributed in such a way as to better reflect the latest preference of motorists. There must be a built-in mechanism to

Column: 869

let the system respond in a timely manner to market trends and consumer demand. If the system is rigid and based on quotas fixed by the authorities from a top-down approach, drastic corrective action will have to be taken from time to time, like the one-time adjustment made in May 1994 when unused motorcycle COEs were redistributed to other categories. This is undesirable.

    However, I do not agree with the Committee's suggestion for two half-yearly quotas and the distribution among the categories to be based on the proportion of vehicles registered in the respective categories in the preceding six-month period. How can the quota in any category change substantially over time when the number of new cars registered in that category has been fixed in the first place by the quota? For example, even if there is the demand for 5,000 Category 1 cars, but if the quota is only 2,000, then only 2,000 Category 1 cars can be registered subject only to those registered using Open Category COEs and perhaps those COEs from higher categories if this option is allowed in the future.

    Perhaps the Government should study the feasibility of allowing COEs from any category to be used to register cars in another category subject to payment of the appropriate transfer fees and an additional levy. This will remove the one year lag between deregistration and recycling of replacement COEs. What this means effectively is that it will better match the supply with the demand of those who are scrapping their vehicles. This is a sensible suggestion. The Government accepts this recommendation and will implement the new quota formula for this quota year, beginning May 1999.

    So the 1999 quota will be based on projected deregistration this year plus 3% growth of the vehicle population as at 31st December 1998. LTA will estimate the deregistrations for each year based on the trends of the last few years. If there is any discrepancy between estimate and actual, this will be accounted for in the following year.

The Government agrees in principle with the recommendation to smoothen out the surge in COE supply in the year 2000 and the troughs that would take place before and after.     Next, distribution among categories. The GPC recommended that the Government consider a more dynamic and responsive mechanism to distribute COEs to the different categories. The aim is a laudable one which is to reflect the changing preference of motorists for different kinds of vehicles. We agree that the current system is not flexible enough for this purpose, but some of the projections that we have made suggest that any such proposed mechanism will have a major impact on the vehicle mix. So my Ministry would like to study the implications of this proposed mechanism and other alternatives, if possible, to the current distribution method with the objective of making sure that it is more responsive. In the meantime, we will retain the current distribution method.

    Merging of quota categories. I think this is a recommendation that has generated quite a lot of interest. The GPC recommended that the number of categories for cars be reduced to two while the commercial vehicles and motorcycles remain in their separate categories. Mr Ong Kian Min and Dr Wang Kai Yuen, among others, have expressed concern that this merger will result in the buyers of smaller cars in each category being squeezed out by the buyers of the larger cars. Both Members have also recommended in one form or another, some kind of a scaling factor so that big car owners will pay more than small car owners.

    I think there is no question that when the COE system was first formulated there was this need to address some of the social equity considerations. But from the land transport point of view, it is also clear that there should only be one category of COEs from which all vehicle buyers will bid. The reason is very simple. As far as congestion is concerned, it is the same whether you have a large car or a small car, so the COE as a proxy for the cost of causing that congestion should be the same.

    Having a single category will also provide maximum flexibility to cater to the changing preference for different

Column: 889

types of vehicles. Having a large category, as Dr Wang pointed out, would also reduce price fluctuations. But there are compelling social and business considerations to suggest that we are not ready to implement a single quota category system. So the recommendation to keep, for example, commercial vehicles and motorcycles separate is an acceptable one. The reason is because they have different tax platforms from cars and they also cater to different groups of motorists.

    With regard to Mr Ong's and Dr Wang's suggestion to introduce scaling factors, I think this suggestion was also considered by the GPC, but it was not accepted after the Government gave its view that the VQS is not intended to be a progressive tax measure. Progressivity is already built into the cost of owning a vehicle, especially into our motor car tax structure. For example, when you buy a big car, you pay a higher ARF and more customs duty because these two elements are based on the Open Market Value of the car. So we are already charging a wealth tax on the large car owners via the ARF and the customs duty mechanism. Furthermore, we charge higher road taxes when these cars are put on the road. So the Government feels that there is really no need for us to introduce another progressivity element into another aspect of the land transport tax structure or cost structure, which is in this case the COE. This is a deliberate decision that we have taken. Yes, I agree that people would not mind if Government were to say, "Okay, we are going to have a progressivity element into the COE structure as well." But is it necessary? After all, when we first mooted the COE system, we said that this is to tackle traffic congestion. Let us just leave it at that.

    Yet, having said all that, it is true that a single car category will result in buyers of big cars squeezing out small cars. So as an interim measure, the Government accepts the GPC's recommendations to reduce the number of car categories from four to two. We merge Categories 1 and 2 together, and then we merge Categories 3

Column: 890

and 4 together. Buyers of small cars, by which I refer to Categories 1 and 2, will not have to compete with buyers of bigger cars, those in Categories 3 and 4. If you look at Categories 1 and 2, you will see that the quota premiums have in recent months started to converge. There is still a difference but the difference has come down very sharply. In fact, there was even one occasion when, as Mr Chew Heng Ching pointed out, Category 1 COEs were actually higher than Category 2 COEs. One of the reasons for this was because there was a mismatch of supply and demand, and the supply of Category 1 COEs is very small every month. In that particular month, when there was a surge of buyers for very small cars, Category 1 COEs went up sharply. Having a larger category for small cars, whether it is below 1,000 cc or between 1,000 cc and 1,600 cc, will help to moderate upward pressure on the COE price for the small cars. For Categories 3 and 4, I think it is much less controversial because the two COE premiums are generally similar and so the merging of these two categories makes sense.

This mechanism of the Open Category was implemented when we segmented all the car categories into various compartments. Ideally, as I said earlier, they should all be one. But because of various considerations, we split them up into six. The COE Open Category is a mechanism to cater for changes in the market place. If there is a change in demand for different types of vehicles, the Open Category can cater for this because it can be used to register any type of vehicle.

    As several Members have pointed out, including Dr Wang, the Open Category COEs have been used mainly for the bigger cars. But this has not always been the case. In fact, in recent months, and last year especially, about 40% of Open Category COEs were used to register smaller cars. And in the past, these COEs had also been used to register commercial vehicles. So it is not clear cut. It is not preordained that Open Category COEs are

Column: 891

used for the larger cars. Things do change as the market changes. In conjunction with the review of the quota distribution mechanism, my Ministry will review the proportion of COEs to be allocated to the Open Category. At the moment, it is 25%. We will continue with the 25%, but in the review, we will see whether this figure should be changed.

Column: 892

greater transparency. And it recommended that we try this out in the Open Category. As Members are aware, there are many, many different auction systems in the world and in Singapore. Some are used to auction hogs, some are used to auction cars, some flowers, others stocks and shares, which is a very common example. Each of these systems has its strength and weakness. So we need to look for a system that can suit our specific situation, a system that people generally accept to be fair and transparent.

    There have been many calls from Members in this House as well as members of the public to implement a pay-as-you-bid system. The main reason behind such calls is the belief that a pay-as-you-bid system will result in lower premiums. The thinking is that with the lowest successful bid, people are encouraged to bid high because they do not have to pay. In the pay-as-you-bid system, everybody is more responsible and therefore you bid responsibly. However, if you take a closer scrutiny of the results of the tenders for the last months, if not years, I think you will find that this is not the case, that actually in the current lowest successful bid system, people do not generally bid irresponsibly. My Ministry has analysed the numbers and we do not see any evidence that there is this very irresponsible bidding pattern that people have attributed to the lowest successful bid system.

There is no evidence to suggest that the pay-as-you-bid system is superior to the lowest successful bid system. On the other hand, there are several disadvantages of the pay-as-you-bid system. These are cited in the GPC report and I will not repeat them here, except to say that I agree with the reasons.

    The Government also agrees with the GPC that the open bidding system merits serious consideration. With greater transparency and more information, individuals will be able to make more informed and rational decisions based on the full knowledge of the prevailing market situation. Many Members in this House, including Dr Toh See Kiat and Mr Chew Heng Ching, as well as many others outside, have expressed fears that an open bidding system will irrationally drive up prices, leading to higher premiums. I think all of us attend Seventh Moon auctions. Most of us do anyway. We all cheer when the prices go up. The organisers are happy. The beneficiaries, whether a charity or a grassroots organisation, are also happy. The successful bidders are also happy. Because he is a willing buyer of a product that is being sold to him. It is a scarce commodity. Whether it is "or kim", a piece of black gold, or whether it is an engraved plaque that somebody has put up for auction, this scarce commodity has been sold to the highest bidder. Nobody twisted his arm to bid for it, but he was happy. So it is with COEs.

    In an open bidding system, people who value or who want that COE in that particular month will go for it. They will bid high for it. That is what an auction system is all about. And the revenues from COEs also go towards a good cause, whether it is for roads, MRT, schools, or other public projects. So I think we should not get carried away. The bidding system, whether it is a closed system or an open system, is essentially an auction for a scarce commodity. In itself, any auction system, whether it is an open or closed bidding system, should not lead to higher prices. The price, in this case the COE premium, ultimately will be decided by the bidders, based on information that are available to them, the supply of COEs, the market economy, or their own situation, as Dr Wang pointed out.

    In a closed bid, such information is not readily available. So there is that element of luck involved. You put your bid in. If you

Column: 894

are more informed, you tend to have a higher probability of success. If you are less informed, chances are that you would not get your COE. But in an open system, the bidders will be fully aware of what the prevailing bids are. Their own bid will also be a deliberate one. Every one will have easy access to the same amount of information. So in that respect, I support the view of the GPC that an open bidding system will result in better informed and, hence, more rational and more responsible bidding. I think this is a worthwhile objective which every vehicle buyer will support.

    I understand and it is natural that there will be some anxiety and apprehension about new systems. Some Members including Mr Ong Kian Min have asked: why change, why not stick to the same thing, why introduce uncertainty? The answer is, if we can have something better, why not? So is it better? I think that is a key question. Is it better than what we have today? Is it really a new system? People are anxious because they say this is something new. I think Mr Chay did point out that this is not a new system. Share markets, currency markets trade daily on stock and monetary exchanges on an open bidding system. There are many, many sites on the Internet where open electronic bids are quite common. E-bay is one that comes to mind. I think there are many others, both overseas and in Singapore.

    Cars are now being sold on an open bidding system electronically. Traders in New Zealand buy second-hand cars from Japan, and they bid for them on an open electronic bidding system, a system which incidentally is managed and operated out of Singapore. Second-hand motor traders in Singapore, I know, are now thinking of using a similar system to allow people to buy and sell second-hand cars, again using an on-line auction system.

    So I do not think there is really that much to fear about an open bidding system transacted on-line. However, I do agree that there are many technical issues that need to be settled before we go ahead with this system. We need to settle things

Column: 895

like how to prevent last minute bidding, how to prevent manipulation, and so on. My Ministry will study the mechanics of this open bidding system in greater detail. And we hope to introduce a trial of this system within a year. While the Government is accepting in-principle the trial, we have not finalised whether this will be held in the Open Category, and we are open to suggestions on how to implement the trial. I would like to assure Members that the Government will carefully consider all the possible pitfalls of the open bidding system before we go ahead with it. As Dr Toh See Kiat mentioned, there are many reservations or possible pitfalls in such a system. In the meantime, we will stick with the current closed system, based on the lowest successful bid price. We will not change that.

    As far as information is concerned, Mr Ang Mong Seng asked for more information. We will gladly give members of the public all the information that is already available at LTA. We will try to put them onto the LTA web-site. In fact, many members of the public who were involved in the dialogue sessions with the GPC were not even aware that information of the tender results, including their own tenders, with their IC numbers and their tender price, were available at LTA.     Sir, let me conclude by saying that the review of the VQS has been a worthwhile exercise. There is a general consensus that the VQS should be retained. It is serving its purpose. Nevertheless, there are several recommendations to improve the system. The Government has accepted most of the recommendations. Others would be considered for possible implementation at a later date, such as open bidding. I am confident that these changes will result in a system which is fairer and more efficient and which, hopefully, we do not need to tinker with for quite a long while.
